vectorData.altText: 14. What colour is acute blood in a CT image?
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
That’s right! The colour of extravasated blood in CT images changes over time, but in the acute phase it is bright white.

CSF is black in CT, as seen here in the lateral ventricles (A). Acute blood (a bleed) is white in CT. 
In a subarachnoid hemorrhage, a cerebral artery bleeds into the subarachnoid space. Acute blood (white) is seen in spaces normally filled with CSF (black), such as sulci (B) and cisterns     (C). Blood in the sulci makes the gyri easier to see; this is called “gyral enhancement”.

Remember, a cistern is an expanded subarachnoid space. You know about the lumbar cistern, inferior to the tip of the spinal cord. Similarly, there are cisterns associated with the brain, such as the interpeduncular, pontine and superior cisterns, as well as the cisterna magna.
